Topic.Title: Get ready for March 18

Message.Msg: An at-the-money weekly call option for just one week would cost you over $900 just for time premium alone. When I trade the weeklies, I like to buy at least 10.00 in-the-money in order to reduce time premium. Most traders tend to scale in their buys and scale out when selling. The 470 weekly is currently around $1700. Of course traders would rather buy the mini options for around $170 than try to time in the more expensive regular options. Also, the mini options would permit more investors to buy deeper ITM calls rather than pay huge time premiums for ATM calls. Keep your eye on the pricing difference between the regular and mini options. Theoretically, the mini should be one tenth that of the regular, but in reality the mini will most likely be greater than one tenth of the regular. If the difference is large enough, expect a lot of arbitrage plays to be done - long the regular options / short the mini options.

Message.Msg: desperate move to regain market share

Message.Title: Apple’s New Lightning to HDMI Adapter Shows Why Apple is in Rapid Decline
Message.Msg: Apple’s decision to switch to Lightning adapters, which rendered existing cables and accessories virtually useless, was met with widespread dismay from Apple users. The Lightning cables and adapters are expensive, since they started from US$29. In particular, the Lightning-to-HDMI cable is not only very expensive ($49) but it is also worse than the older 30-Pin cable in several ways. Apple users have been complaining about the bad video quality of the new adapter, as well as the lack of an ability to play 1080p video. Because of these complaints, Panic Software took apart the adapter to see what is inside, and discovered an ARM CPU. In fact, the adapter streams video to devices using AirPlay. Apple is using AirPlay to stream videos because the Lightning connector does not output video, even though the old 30-Pin one did youtube it

Topic.Title: Get ready for March 18

Message.Msg: Because more people will be able to buy options due to their lower costs. Have you ever observed the difference between the $5 tables and the $50 tables at a casino. The $5 tables are almost always full while the $50 tables are usually mostly empty (except maybe during prime hours). Whenever someone buys a call option, the market maker will match the order with someone who wants to short the call. If he cannot find someone, then the MM could take on the short call position himself. But then he will hedge his position by usually buying shares of the stock.

Topic.Title: qnx tsunami on its way..

Message.Msg: As a microkernel-based OS, QNX is based on the idea of running most of the OS in the form of a number of small tasks, known as servers. This differs from the more traditional monolithic kernel, in which the operating system is a single very large program composed of a huge number of "parts" with special abilities. In the case of QNX, the use of a microkernel allows users (developers) to turn off any functionality they do not require without having to change the OS itself; instead, those servers are simply not run. The system is quite small, with earlier versions fitting on a single floppy disk.[1] QNX Neutrino (2001) has been ported to a number of platforms and now runs on practically any modern CPU that is used in the embedded market. This includes the PowerPC, x86 family, MIPS, SH-4 -- and the closely inter-related family of ARM, StrongARM and XScale CPUs. QNX offers a license for non-commercial & academic users.[2] QNX Neutrino is widely used as the basis for automotive electromechanical components, for industrial control systems, medical instruments, defense systems, nuclear power plants, and other mission-critical applications.[3] The BlackBerry PlayBook tablet computer designed by BlackBerry uses a version of QNX as the primary operating system. Devices from BlackBerry running the BlackBerry 10 operating system are also QNX based.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Unless Apple's profits and free cash flow are going to shrink going forward, the company's shares are cheap. They are priced at 10 times trailing as well as expected fiscal year 2013 earnings and roughly 7 times after extracting cash and securities on reserve in addition to the earnings from those holdings. Nevertheless, shares will only rise if the company provides new reasons to buy the stock. Apple shares hit a low of $437 and some of the extreme-pessimism deflating has allowed the stock to halt its decline though any rebound will need a large catalyst such as a interesting update to a major product, a potential blockbuster new product, or an announcement of a substantially larger dividend or stock buyback.

Message.Title: Buffett on Apple/Reporter on CNBC by Barrons
Message.Msg: SPEAKING OF APPLE, and what ails it, Berkshire Hathaway's Warren Buffett spent three hours on CNBC last Monday morning dispensing his customary wit and wisdom on a variety of topics, including Apple. Asked about the stock's 41% drop in the last five months, Buffett reminded viewers that Berkshire has tanked by 50% four different times in its history and always came roaring back. Each time, someone advised Buffett to pay a dividend to boost the shares, and each time Buffett demurred. Asked about hedge-fund activist David Einhorn's call for Apple to issue preferred shares, Buffett's counsel was simple. "I would ignore him," he said. "I would run the business to create the most value over the next five or 10 years. You can't run a business to try to run the stock up everyday." CNBC's commentators quickly ignored that patient view and resumed their hand-wringing about Apple after the segment.

Message.Title: Credit Agricole downgraded Apple price target of $505 from $575
Message.Msg: Credit Agricole downgraded Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) from Buy to Outperform with a price target of $505 from $575. Analyst Avi Silver said he was expects weak iPhone trends in the June quarter. The weakness is tied to increased competition ahead of the iPhone 5s launch. Silver also said he wasn't expecting iPhones with large screen this year, although they are "much needed".

Message.Title: Apple's Suppliers Had A Terrible February
Message.Msg: More bad news for Apple. Brian White of Topeka Capital says his "Apple Monitor" was terrible for February. White, who is a mega-bull on Apple, maintains an "Apple Monitor," which tracks the results of key Apple suppliers. When their results are good, it usually means good things for Apple. When the results are bad, watch out. White says the February results for his Apple Monitor were down 31 percent sequentially, which compares to the typical 8 percent decline. Even if you factor in the Chinese New Year, he still says it's bad. "The Apple Monitor came up short this February and delivered the worst February we have on record," says White. He tries to soothe concerned investors by saying, "That said, we are noticing that most of the preliminary Taiwan Monitors experienced weaker than average trends this February and certain Monitors are delivering one of the weaker performances on record."

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Credit Agricole's Avi Silver "downgrades" Apple to Outperform from Buy, while lowering his PT to $505 from $575. Silver expects iPhone sales to be weak in the June quarter thanks to growing competition ahead of a 5S launch (presumably the Galaxy S IV takes center stage here). He also doesn't expect an iPhone with a larger screen, which (like others) he considers "much needed," to arrive this year.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: Tim Cook, From Apple's fiscal Q1 2013 Earnings Call: "I know there has been lots of rumors about order cuts and so forth and so let me just take a moment to make a comment on these. I don't want to comment on any particular rumor because I would spend my life doing that but I would suggest it's good to question the accuracy of any kind of rumor about build plans and also stress that even if a particular data point were factual it would be impossible to accurately interpret the data point as to what it meant for our overall business because the supply chain is very complex and we obviously have multiple sources for things, yields might vary, supply performance can vary. The beginning inventory positions can vary, I mean there is just an inordinate long list of things that would make any single data point not a great proxy for what's going on

Message.Title: Apple is getting close to being fully valued....for now.
Message.Msg: Its not that Apple isn't making a bazzillion bucks, its just that growth is stagnant and regressing a bit. There's also many other options, very good options available to consumers that didn't exist previously. Apple bulls seem to be blind to this glaring fact. Really, can't you "feel" that the euphoria has run dry? People are no longer waiting like a starved animal to get their hands on Apple's next updated product. It happens in all industries. Look at someone like Lady Gaga for example. For a couple years she was the hottest thing on the planet to younger people. But now, she's starting to lose it. In a few more years, you won't even hear about her. Granted, that's an extreme case and in a few years you'll certainly see Apple products on the shelves and wanted by consumers, although they'll most likely be just another vendor and not kind of the mountain. A fact you need to confront now if expecting the stock to climb back to $700 which I don't see happening unless they can somehow develop another category killer product...which is possible.

Message.Title: AAPL, GOOG, AMZN or NFLX?
Message.Msg: All are great companies, although Netflix is a little more questionable. If you had $100k to invest today for three years, what do you take? I'd have to take Apple. All trade on sentiment, and I can't see much more upside in the other three. My opinion, Apple is trading at a "worst case scenario." Apple would seem to be the safest pick, although they're doing nothing right in regards to stock management at this time. I don't think a CEO needs to respond to every 10% dip, but 40% should be a cause for action. And the theory that a great new Samsung phone is the end of Apple is ignorant. If Apple comes out with something spectacular, and they have many times in the past, is that the end of Samsung? Of course not.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: Apple (AAPL) has held the top spot of Adage's portfolio for some time now and this last quarter the position increased by 1% (in shares). However, due to the decline in Apple's share price, the percentage Apple takes up in the portfolio decreased from 3.21 to 2.6%. Apple's shares have been brought down lately as its payout policies have come into question and holders have started to question its ability to grow at the pace it has previously. Shares of Apple trade at $429.80 per share with a P/E of only 9.8, well below the five-year average P/E of 15.6.

Message.Title: Apple suppliers Foxconn, TSMC to each add 5,000 job
Message.Msg: Monday, March 11, 2013, 11:39 am Apple suppliers Foxconn, TSMC to each add 5,000 job By Kevin Bostic Two of Apple's top suppliers are reportedly adding staff in apparent anticipation of an uptick in demand for their services. TSMC, which manufactures Apple's custom A-series chips, and Hon Hai Precision, parent company of Foxconn and longtime Apple manufacturing partner, will add 5,000 new jobs each, Reuters reported on Monday, citing the Taiwanese Economic Daily. The two companies have apparently begun posting recruitment notices at events designed for graduating Taiwanese university students. For Hon Hai, the new hiring surge is the largest of its kind in recent years. Hon Hai will reportedly be hiring largely research and development personnel. Those workers will head into automated production, e-commerce, and robots. TSMC, meanwhile, is recruiting largely for equipment managers. The new hiring may indicate that Apple and its suppliers are gearing up for a new wave of Apple products. Apple CEO Tim Cook said earlier this year that Apple's product line was "chock full of incredible stuff," though Cook declined to go into specifics on what consumers could expect. Cook also cautioned against reading too much into any Apple supply chain happenings. The company, Cook said, sources its materials from a wide range of suppliers, so looking to any one or two particular suppliers is unlikely to give true insight as to Apple's plans or fortunes. Monday's report seems to fly in the face of other reports from analysts that "channel checks" showed Apple suppliers suffering through a rough February. CNN relayed on Monday Topeka Capital analyst Brian White's findings, which saw a 31 percent decline in sales companies examined by White's "Apple Monitor." Hon Hai, according to White, saw a 25 percent month-over-month drop in sales for February.

The data here is based on Millennial 's ad impressions, and doesn't represent the entire market. (It's possible more Android apps are powered by AdMob ads, which could explain the disparity.) Still, it's an interesting data point. Read more: http://www.businessinsider.com/millenial-ad-revenue-2011-5#ixzz2NFOuxTXq

Message.Title: AAPL PT Lowered To 505, No Apple Phablet This Year..
Message.Msg: Shares of Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) are down more than 1 percent Monday morning following an earlier downgrade from Credit Agricole's Avi Silver . The analyst now rates Apple shares an Outperform, down from Buy previously, and reduced the price target from $575 to $505 . Silver lowered his iPhone shipment estimate for Q3 from 33 million to 29 million amid increasing competition and ahead of the anticipated unveiling of the next version of the iPhone. The analyst's FY13 and FY14 estimates were also lowered as a result of the more conservative iPhone unit estimate. Silver said he expects an iPhone mini later this year but warned he does not expect to see a larger-screen iPhone. With Apple shares last trading at $426.56 , Silver's new price target still represents potential upside of more than 18 percent.

Topic.Title: AAPL Versus GOOG Net Income Growth

Message.Msg: Perhaps, but the numbers are similar for 2010 to 2011. I suppose what surprises me more is not that they ignore Apple's growth rate. As you said, the prevailing conventional wisdom is that Apple's growth is over. Time will tell. No. What really surprises me is why GOOG commands such a high PE (now nearly 26) when it grew only 9%. In fact, they grew 12.6% from 2010 to 2011, so their growth is slowing and either rate is far below Apple's which now has a PE of 9.5. In contrast, Apple's net income growth from 2010 to 2011 was "only" 46%. So it's growth is accelerating. Even if Apple saw a big decrease in growth, that would still put it, at least, two to three times that of GOOG. Let's suppose AAPL's 2011 to 2012 growth of 93% was a isolated spike. That would imply it might "drop" back to around 45%. How terrible! How much do people expect GOOG's growth rate to suddenly increase in order to support its valuation? And likewise, how much do they expect AAPL's to decline. Consider this: What if AAPL's growth rate dropped half and GOOG's doubled. That would mean: GOOG: 18% growth. AAPL: 46.5% growth Which deserves a PE of 9.5 and which deserves a PE of 25?

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: The ever-bullish Brian White reports his Apple Monitor, which tracks the sales of component suppliers that depend heavily on Apple , saw a 31% M/M drop in February, its worst performance on record for the month. Foxconn parent Hon Hai saw a 25% M/M drop. Baird's William Power, meanwhile, says his firm's semiconductor checks indicate iPhone/iPad orders are in-line with his estimates, but below consensus. White maintains an $888 PT, and Power a $465 PT.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Credit Agricole's Avi Silver "downgrades" Apple to Outperform from Buy, while lowering his PT to $505 from $575. Silver expects iPhone sales to be weak in the June quarter thanks to growing competition ahead of a 5S launch (presumably the Galaxy S IV takes center stage here). He also doesn't expect an iPhone with a larger screen, which (like others) he considers "much needed," to arrive this year.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: In 2012, Apple announced its dividend and buyback program on Monday, March 19th. It has almost been a year since that announcement. Apple's "cash-hoarding" behavior makes it more likely to be an annual dividend growth stock than one that throws away money on acquisitions or large one-time dividends. Maybe, March 18th, 2013 is the day Apple announces something about its cash again.

Message.Title: iWatch will TETHER TO an iPad
Message.Msg: Tethering is a process that allows the iPad to share a cellular data Internet connection provided by a device such as an iPhone, portable 3G router or a smartphone. All models of the iPad are equipped with Bluetooth and Wi-Fi wireless connectivity, and either system can be used to tether the iPad to an Internet-equipped device.

Topic.Title: iWatch will TETHER TO an iPad

Message.Msg: Apple has a team of about 100 product designers working on a wristwatch-like device that may perform some of the tasks now handled by the iPhone and iPad, people familiar with the company’s plans said last month. Features under consideration include letting users make calls, see the identity of incoming callers and check map coordinates, said one of the people, who asked not to be identified because the plans aren’t public. It would also house a pedometer for counting steps and sensors for monitoring health-related data, such as heart rates, this person said. Apple seeks to introduce the device as soon as this year, this person said. Apple has filed at least 79 patent applications that include the word “wrist,” including one for a device with a flexible screen, powered by kinetic energy.

Topic.Title: AAPL Versus GOOG Net Income Growth

Message.Msg: That would be a valid point if Apple was being stingy about spending to develop its business. But even while "hoarding" cash, Apple reported 2012 capital investments of $14 billion which is more than Google and Intel combined. Somehow, I don't think that Apple has any difficulty finding plenty of money to plow back into the business. Apple can do so while maintaining the bottom line because it is very disciplined and well run in terms of financials and operations. In contrast, Google spends an awful lot of money on the weird little projects that have nothing to do with their means of revenue generation which is, basically, adsense, adwords, and related services. I'm not saying that Apple does not spend money on R&D for unconventional possible products, but they don't blow their money like Google does.

Message.Title: Samsung Utterly Dominates Apple In China's Smartphone Market - Business Insider – 4 hours ago
Message.Msg: By Nicholas Carlson Samsung is smoking Apple in China. With 11 percent of the market, Apple is actually the number three player, trailing Samsung and Lenovo. Samsung is decidedly stronger, reports the Yonhap News Agency: Samsung Electronics sold 30.06 million smartphones in China last year, up from 10.90 million units a year earlier, garnering a 17.7 percent market share, according to the data by market researcher Strategy Analytics. Last year's market share represents a 5.3 percentage point increase from the previous year. It also marks the first time that Samsung Electronics has become the top smartphone seller in the Chinese market since it started selling the device in 2009.

Topic.Title: AAPL Versus GOOG Net Income Growth

Message.Msg: Well, that's the $1,000,000,000,000 question, isn't it? If we knew what the 2012 to 2013 growth rate is going to be, then we would all be billionaires. I'm just saying that even if Apple's growth rate plummeted by 50%, it would be 46% which hardly indicates a PE below 10. The problem is that the decline in the share price represents a huge overreaction to the possibility of a slowdown because, for Apple, even such a slowdown would leave it with a much higher growth rate than Google. Another thing to consider, not directly related to AAPL, is that GOOG's recent run to over $80 is eerily similar to AAPL's run to $700. If I owned GOOG, I would be selling before the "Apple effect" takes its toll.

Topic.Title: AAPL Versus GOOG Net Income Growth

Message.Msg: People said the same thing during the period in which they grew 93%. The "new" iPhone that was released at the start of FY 2012 was the iPhone 4S. Remember how everyone complained that it was not the "5" and that is was "basically the same" as the 4? No Innovation. Likewise, the "new" iPad was criticized as being, basically, the same. "Just a retina display and a faster processor," is what people said. No innovation. So during the fiscal year of "no innovation," Apple increased net income by 93%. All this talk about not innovating anymore is a bunch of meaningless nonsense. What does it even mean? It is a meaningless platitude. And what "innovations" have competitors like Samsung introduced? Larger screens? When Apple introduce different sized screens (iPhone 5 and iPad Mini) people say that is evidence they are out of ideas. But ask what makes Samsung so great, and people will tell you "larger screens." So are different screen sizes innovation or not? And isn't the Galaxy IV and update of the III which is an update of the II just as the 5 is an update of the 4S which was an update of the 4, etc.? That is how technology works. Every year, the devices get smaller, lighter, and more powerful. That is the basic definition of Moore's Law. A phone is a phone. Even the original iPhone was not the first phone with its functionality, it was just an improvement over what was available. And each successive model is an improvement. It is not about innovation, it is about continuous improvement.

Message.Title: Gamco manager bullish on Apple
Message.Msg: Here's the article: Apple Will Announce Plans for Cash Hoard, Gamco Says: Tom Keene By Karl Baker - Mar 11, 2013 11:53 AM CT Facebook Share LinkedIn Google +1 2 COMMENTS Print QUEUE Q Apple Inc. (AAPL) will announce plans for its growing pile of cash by next month, according to Howard Ward, chief investment officer at Gamco Investors Inc. Apple, which has been grappling with investor criticism over what to do with its $137.1 billion in cash and investments, will add $42 billion in earnings to that sum in 2013, Ward said. Greenlight Capital Inc.’s David Einhorn has been urging Cupertino, California-based Apple to issue high-yielding preferred shares to spread the funds among investors. Enlarge image Apple Inc. fell 0.9 percent to $427.66 at 12:22 p.m. in New York. Before today, the stock had declined 19 percent this year, compared with an 8.8 percent increase in the S&P 500 Index. Photographer: Lam Yik Fei/Bloomberg “We’re going to get an announcement from the company as to how they intend to reallocate some of their cash,” Ward said in an interview today on Bloomberg Radio’s “Surveillance” with Tom Keene. “They will put a floor under their stock at a higher price than it is today.” Apple fell 0.9 percent to $427.66 at 12:22 p.m. in New York. Before today, the stock had declined 19 percent this year, compared with an 8.8 percent increase in the S&P 500 Index. Ward compared Apple’s shares to JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) stock a year ago after the bank announced a multibillion-dollar loss at the hands of one trader. “The stock was beaten up and it was at 30 dollars a share, and now it’s 50,” he said. Apple is the largest holding in Gamco’s (GBL) fund, Ward said. To contact the reporter on this story: Karl Baker in New York at kbaker30@bloomberg.net To contact the editor responsible for this story: Tom Giles at tgiles5@bloomberg.net More News: U.S. · Stocks · Technology Industry · Consumer Technology · Apple

Message.Title: March 19th - anyone else think AAPL will use this opportunity?
Message.Msg: This is the PR anniversary for the dividend and share buyback. It would give them an excuse to use this date as significant instead of "re-acting" to market pressure. It shows they are in control of their own agenda. AAPL is very concerned about being seen NOT to react to pressure. Maybe shock and awe? I am thinking bring the $10bn buyback forward to this Q and tag on ano $50bn for good measure. Result = the stock jumps but they still get to buyback 10% of the company and also get a better return (by not having to pay the $10.60 per annum on the 10%) than they are currently are by just hoarding the cash and by leaving it in Treasuries. Question? if they buy back shares do they first have to repatriate cash and hence pay taxes? or can they not just purchase on a foreign exchange where AAPL is also traded (London or Frankfurt?) Time to buy!!!!!

Message.Title: Apple may use Intel
Message.Msg: United Evening News: According to Daiwa, TSMC's major customer Gualcomm and Taiwan's leading handset chip designer MediaTek have placed 28nm orders with TSMC rival GlobalFoundries. Such moves may force TSMC to lower its products prices, Daiwa said. Moreover, it said, United Microelectronics Corp., the world's second largest chip foundry after TSMC, is expected to begin providing 28 nm products from Q3 this year, a development that could add up to price cut pressure on TSMC. On the widely watched developments in Apple's next-generation of chipset or processor A7, Daiwa forecast that Samsung may dominate 50 percent of A7 orders, TSMC gets 40 percent, and Intel secures the remaining 10 percent. Late last month, TSMC's longtime client Altera struck a deal with Intel to collaborate in moving to 14 nm production. The Intel-Altera deal marked an end to TSMC's 20-year dominance as the U.S.-based phone-network processors maker's sole foundry service supplier. Less

Topic.Title: Oppeheimers Carter Worth Calls The Bottom AGAIN!

Message.Msg: March 11, 2013 1:54 PM EDT Oppenheimer Chief Market Technician Carter Worth today reiterated his controversial call on Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL). From a technical perspective, Apple's chart is admittedly "terrible", noted the analyst, but despite this, and despite the unpopularity of the trade, he thinks the chart "so bad it's good". "In having retraced all of said move, a move that began with a gap on January 25th, 2012, a gap that now has been filled, AAPL shares have expunged a great deal of the exuberance and hubris of the past year," wrote the technician. With the fast money shaken out, Worth thinks Apple stock is "back on trend" so to speak, and he believes it will recover to $525. Worth is negative on the S&P 500, and sees the two as a 'pairs trade'. Since making the call on January 28th, the S&P has gained 3.2 percent. Apple, meanwhile, has declined 1.9 percent.

Message.Title: One Extreme to the Other
Message.Msg: What is it about the market that it must always go from one extreme to the other? Like say, AAPL from $700 to $430. But what I am talking about here is the dividend. Starting on February 27th, the price has been down because so many idiots expected a dividend increase announcement at the meeting even though the initial announcement of the dividend in 2012 was NOT at the annual meeting, but was on March 19, 2012. So for the last couple of weeks or so, it seems many were convinced that there would be no announcement of a dividend increase and the stock price reflected that. Now people finally seem to be realizing the obvious, the the announcement was always going to be in March and very likely early next week. So what do we get now? Instead of NO dividend increase, people are talking about a $30 special dividend. They are setting themselves up for disappointment just like those who expected an announcement at the annual meeting on February 27th. There is NOT going to be a special dividend. Don't set yourself up for an expectation that there will be. There IS going to be an announcement of an increase to the regular quarterly dividend. The only real question is how large. I suppose, if I let myself hope, they could do something big like increase it by 50%. But my expectation is for something like 15% give or take 5%.

Topic.Title: IS APPLE Giving Away $30 Billion Of It's Cash..............

Message.Msg: A special dividend is not "giving away" anything. It is a transfer of assets from the company to its shareholders. There seems to be no plausible scenario where AAPL needs anywhere near the cash on hand PLUS all they will generate in coming quarters. Transferring it to shareholders so they can use it according to their priorities only makes sense. Not only are the cash balances much larger than Jobs had, the rates of return on them are much lower than he or anyone would have predicted.

Topic.Title: So all this was because of a rumor a large fund may be buying?

Message.Msg: The spike today was not related to rumors that a fund is about to purchase shares of aapl. Had that been the case, the stock would have dropped precipitously in the ah session. Rather, it was a result of persistent rumors about an imminent dividend increase or share buyback plan. It seems that, unless and until those plans turn out to be nonexistent, shares will further rise in the short term.

Message.Title: APPLE: Oppenheimer Asset Management chief technician Carter Worth
Message.Msg: Oppenheimer Asset Management chief technician Carter Worth, for one, sees Apple as a possible battered beauty ready to rebound. He says Apple's time may have come, after going on a round trip, shooting to $705 in September, back to a low of $419 last week. "We are buyers here. A terrible chart, which we believe, is 'so bad that it's good,'" he wrote in a note.Worth, meanwhile, writes the sell-off in Apple is "mature in terms of magnitude (-$286...-40.6 percent) and duration (5-1/2 months in the making) leaving the stock right back at the level where the euphoric, parabolic move of 2012 got under way." Apple has now retraced the move, Worth said, beginning on January 26 with a gap up that has since been filled. "(Apple) shares have expunged a great deal of the exuberance and hubris of the past year," Worth wrote. The 40 percent decline also has shaken out "fast money" that started chasing the stock in January of 2012. Apple is now the farthest below its 150-day moving average at any time since the stock market collapsed in the financial crisis in 2008/2009, Worth noted. That could mean the stock would move back toward the 150-day moving average, and the meet the "smoothing mechanism" around the $525 level. Redler said there are buyers at higher levels, rather than lowers, as traders watch to see if it can hold a floor. While Apple may be ready to bounce, the S&P 500 could be getting ready to head in the opposite direction, Worth wrote. The two diverged in the fall, when the S&P began its current rally and Apple sold off. (Read More: Buy Tech Without 'Cool Factor': Forrest) "Bottom line: We are buyers of AAPL here, playing for a prospective rebound...and sellers of the market here, playing for a prospective sell off," Worth notes. As for the S&P, it traded places with the S&P twice, showing out-performance in February but then giving it all back.

Message.Title: Next Apple iPhone May Have NFC Technology
Message.Msg: iPhone 5 Apple's next generation iPhone may feature technology that will enable users to pay for purchases with a tap of their phone. (Read More: Apple Chart Looks 'So Bad That It's Good') According to an AppleInsider story, the China Times is reporting that the next iPhone, which it's speculated will be called the iPhone 5S, will have near-field communication technology (NFC) and a fingerprint sensor. (Read More: Near Field Communication — the Next Mobile Boost?) Apple is expected to launch the latest iPhone model in June or July, according to Jefferies analyst Peter Misek. (Read More: When to Expect Apple iTV, iPhone 5S and Tablets: Analyst) The NFC chip would allow contactless payments, and a sensor under the home button would serve as a way for users to authorize the payment with their fingerprint, according to the report. Talk that Apple might add fingerprint sensors to iPhones has circulated since last July, when the company bought the mobile security company AuthenTec for $356 million. AuthenTec designs fingerprint sensors and other products for mobile security. (Read More: Apple Smartwatch Out of 'Experimentation Phase': Report ) The latest iPhone models already have an e-wallet-type app called Passbook, which stores a user's boarding passes, loyalty cards, coupons and movie tickets in one place. Items stored in Passbook require QR codes for scanning, however. An NFC chip in Apple's iPhone would allow tickets, coupons and

Message.Title: Special vs Regular Dividend?
Message.Msg: I'd rather see a modest increase in the regular dividend for Apple common shareholders. This would show long term value for common shareholders in that the future dividend will probably keep increasing. I don't like the idea of a $30 per share special dividend. The one time give away of cash would reduce the possibility of future increases in the regular dividend for common shareholders.

Topic.Title: So all this was because of a rumor a large fund may be buying?

Message.Msg: Next earnings are a risk factor for this stock. Earnings will most likely be flat to down, which will precipitate probably the final leg down in the stock, probably to the 325-350 range. This is primarily my personal feelings here, but i have in fact been right (not on this board) calling each leg down in the stock from the high 600's, after the initial sell off. My sentiment was based on the huge profit pressure that had built up in the stock. Once the glass cracked, the leaking has had to continue, inevitably. I actually hold some long positions here, but i'm anticipating that i'll have to average down 1 or 2 more times to lower my coast basis. In the LONG run, Apple is definitely a winner. They've got much up their sleeve in terms of future market penetration, on a number of fronts, in communications, education, gov't/commercial, the automotive and medical fields, and so forth.

Topic.Title: REASON AAPL IS UP

Message.Msg: Hey squeeze, couldn't agree more on all points, and also been thinking about the goog pair... thinking they meet at around 600 by EOY. Crazy to watch the whiplash sentiment of the flavor of the month. Two quarters ago goog was on the outs, missed on the Q, keyword prices were supposedly declining, facebook was supposed to launch search and take share...and now? Goog to 1000 whatever valuation that implies!!!! What a joke. Don't even need a catalyst here, just reverting to trend when life doesn't end for AAPL as we know it gets us back to 600 with a modet 13-14x EPS / FCF multiple. New developments or a multiple beyond that is just gravy. The type of trading we saw today is exactly what happens when sentiment hits a nadir and panic selling hits a peak. The sellers get exhausted and at some point, say when there is blurb about payment processing tech, the panic buyers jump in... Now if aapl was still the street darling, that same blurb would have sent aapl up 5% and MA and V each down 8%. And that is exactly when I would stay clear of the name.... trading like today doesn't take any news at all from where we are. Speculation and the divi response a few weeks ago saw a pop to 480... on actual news we can be up 15% in a week and trending higher...

Message.Title: Emotions turning - upside based on sentiment, not valuation
Message.Msg: Been a long rocky ride down from 700. During that entire decline the normal cycle played out - first the analysts said buy the dips, then they said it was a great value, then they turned negative and almost universally lowered price targets and growth rates. Forget the name Apple - this story has been repeated for many stocks. Now the analysts are universally neutral or modestly bullish, but you see no $1000 price forecasts. In the meantime, since the stock was at $700, the SP500 has rallied 10%. That is quite a move, both absolute and relative. With sentiment extremely negative, and earnings expectations very low, it wouldn't surprise me at all if AAPL outperforms the SP500 starting right now. No need to make a big bet, just consider that with all the negative news the stock stays above $400, and every time it gets to $420 the buyers move it higher. The negative momentum is waning - even if you hate AAPL, it's time to play for the upside.

Topic.Title: Samsung Galaxy S4 has 8 cores

Message.Msg: There's a lot of clueless haters on here. When someone goes out and spends $700 on a flipping phone you bet they're gonna read up on it or ask sme questions. And when you're locked into a 2 year contract you bet you're gonna get the best and newest tech. Speed doesn't matter as most people don't read benchmark results but everyone understands 8 cores is twice as many as quad core and that's a good thing and this would give Samsung a huge edge which is why Samsung spent the extra money for this CPU. This is exactly like screen size or resolution or camera mega pixels. Most people know its not so much the pixels that count but they always go for the phone with the most pixels. And here again Samsung will have a hue advantage even if real life demos show the iPhone 5 is better. And this is exactly why I've been saying for 2 months now that Apple will release the iPhone 5S most likely next month and this is why supplier orders are down. And if I'm right we're gonna spike $100 in a week cause it would mean 6 more months of really high sales and by October the iPhone 6 will come out right in time for Christmas so apple will blow past $800 in huge demand for new iPhones. If apple fails to do this then Samsung will kill them in the next 6 months with the S4. Bank on it. I hope that wimp Cook finally gets it - consumers will no longer buy any #$%$ apple puts out.
